Teachers will always communicate to students how they plan to take attendance each day.

Joliet Central High School Student Places First in Joliet and 14th in State for Stock Market Simulation Contest

Joliet native Lizbeth Avilés volunteers through the Spanish Community Center to teach her Intro to Investing lessons at Joliet Central and West High School. She provides her expertise in a stock market simulation contest where students place real time stock orders online and compete with students all over the state.

Through this partnership, Miss Avilés kicked off the second year of the program in November 2019 and concluded in February 2020 with Steve Visser’s Orientation to Business class with 57 students (West) and Suzanne Haberkorn’s Personal Finance class with 48 students (Central).

Javier Reyes (Central Senior ‘2020) had no prior experience with stocks and dominated the contest with his extraordinary 36% portfolio return at the end of the 7 week program ranking him 1st in Joliet and 14th in the state.

Photo taken prior to COVID-19 School Closure

We are contacting you regarding important vaccination requirements for your senior student. Twelfth grade students enrolled at Joliet West must provide documentation of meningococcal conjugate vaccination (MCV), including the date of administration and a doctor’s signature.

Students who do not provide proof of vaccination, will not be allowed to attend school in August.

How does the Census work? / ¿Cómo funciona el Censo?
Each household must complete the Census. It’s short and easy to fill out. Census information starts arriving in the mail in mid-March. There are three ways to complete the Census in 2020: by phone, online, or in a paper survey. A Census taker will come to the household in mid-April to get the information if the Census hasn’t been completed yet. Questions during the Census? There will be hotlines to help people who have questions when completing the Census: 1-800-923-8282 or 301-763-INFO (4636).

• The census helps determine which communities get money for important resources like schools, hospitals, and roads.
• The Census affects how much representation (and voice!) Illinois has in congress
• It’s our right to be counted in the Census – the Constitution, the law of the land, says so.

On February 13, fifty students from Joliet Township High School participated in the Young Women’s Luncheon and Career Conversation event hosted by ExxonMobil at their Joliet Refinery. The event consisted of guided conversation with female ExxonMobil employees, and a presentation from Joliet Junior College that provided information on the college’s Technical Program Offerings and Operation Engineering and Technician Program.

“JTHS would like to thank Tricia Simpson for her role in establishing this wonderful opportunity for our students,” said JTHS Director of Strategic Partnerships Brett Marcum. “While she will be moving into retirement at the end of this month, she will continue to impact the Joliet community through this event and many others like it which connect students to the STEM world.”

The ExxonMobil career day programs are an important aspect of JTHS' work to ensure that JTHS students are College and Career ready. JTHS values the opportunities that exist due to the support of community partners such as ExxonMobil.

#JTAchievesTogether

On February 13, 2020, the JTHS Orchestra partnered with the Niles West High School Orchestra to host their First Annual Niles West/JTHS Orchestra Festival Day. The JTHS Orchestra is directed by Peter Lipari, and the Niles West Orchestra is directed by Thomas Chester, who was in Lipari’s first graduating class at Joliet Central High School.

During the event at Niles West High School, the students worked with Dr. Stephen Alltop from Northwestern University who led the students in rehearsing selected pieces. The students then had lunch together, and to end the day, they combined forces by recording the piece they worked on so everyone would have a memento of the exciting day.

Mr. Lipari said of the experience, "Everyone had such a good time with Maestro Alltop. We all learned a lot, enjoyed each other’s company, and are looking forward to repeating the experience again next year."

JTHS appreciates partnering with Niles West High School and looks forward to future opportunities for collaboration for the benefit of the students.

Over the President’s Day Weekend, Joliet West High School wrestler Jeremy Pullen placed third at the IHSA Sectionals at 160 pounds and qualified for the 3A IHSA State Competition. He advances to the IHSA State Wrestling Tournament in Champaign, IL this upcoming weekend, Thursday-Saturday, February 20-22, 2020.

Joliet West Wrestling Coach Chuck Rumpf said, “I am most proud of the perseverance and determination Jeremy has demonstrated in getting this far. He has been close to this accomplishment over the past 3 years and has now broken through to the state tournament. He has earned the distinction of being one of the best wrestlers in the state in his weight class, and I look forward to seeing him compete for a state championship this weekend! I am thankful for his leadership as a captain and his contributions to the program over the last 4 years. His achievements will have a lasting impact.”

JTHS wishes Jeremy the best of luck at the state competition.

Over the President’s Day Weekend, Joliet Central High School bowler Heidi Johnson placed 3rd at the IHSA Girls Bowling Sectional at Moline. She will be competing at The Cherry Bowl in Rockford, IL this Friday, February 21, 2020 with the hopes of advancing to day 2 on Saturday, February 22, 2020.

Joliet Central Athletic Director Jen Doede said, “Heidi continues to grow as a bowler each and every day. She has worked really hard over the last four years to get to where she is at today. She has been a co-captain for our program to help lead the younger girls, along with placing in several different tournaments throughout the season individually. She also became only the second bowler in Central history to have a 1300 series at a tournament! She became an SPC All-Conference bowler this year along with breaking some of her own and school records along the way.”

JTHS wishes Heidi the best of luck at the state competition

Over the President’s Day Weekend, Joliet Central High School wrestler Jayden Perez won the Quincy Wrestling Sectional at the 182 pound weight class. Jayden went 4-0 with wins over Edwardsville, Providence, Plainfield South, and Quincy. Jayden improves his record to 39-4 for the 2020 season. He advances to the IHSA State Wrestling Tournament in Champaign, IL this upcoming weekend, Thursday-Saturday, February 20-22, 2020.

Jayden is looking to become the first state wrestling champion at Joliet Central High School since 1998. He is a captain and has served as a leader throughout the season. Jayden placed in the top three for each tournament this season, including winning the Pontiac Tournament in December. He is an SPC All-Conference wrestler as well. Jayden set goals prior to the season of being a state medalist and he is determined to get there.

JTHS wishes Perez the best of luck at the state competition.

Joliet West High School Senior Anthony Maland went on air with WGN Morning News at 9:15 a.m. on December 26. Maland is the founder of his own nonprofit, Recycled Rhythm, Inc., an organization dedicated to refurbishing used percussion instruments & gifting them to children with special needs and terminal illnesses.

What inspired Maland to take the leap into founding his own nonprofit while also juggling student life and musicianship?

“I was at a gig in Morris and I met a four-year-old boy who had cancer. When I was done playing, I let him play the drums. After that, I saw a video of him doing music therapy. He is now cancer free,” Maland said. “But what inspired me the most to start this charity is that in 2018 I was diagnosed with a touch of autism-spectrum disorder. So, I decided to use my diagnosis to help other kids by music, the way it helps me. I love seeing the recipient’s faces when they see they are getting their own drums for free.”

Joliet Township High School has joined the Illinois State Board of Education in the Illinois 5Essentials Survey to gather important data about our school climate and learning conditions.
